title: After Theresa May, Boris Johnson? – Cartoon | Opinion
content: Brexit has effectively given the Tories a pass on proper governing. It remains what it’s always been; a squalid internecine argument amongst the Tory Party, and it’s shameful really that they’ve dragged the rest of us into this. It’s highly disturbing but entirely indicative that every potential leader (and therefore next PM) is already defining their suitability wholly in terms of what shade of shit they can deliver a Brexit in. They’re not even bothering with talking about anything else that should concern the leader of a nation - health, education, welfare, the economy stupid etc etc. While it’s clearly the burning issue of the day for these dim bulb Conservatives, the rest of us have to get on with the realities of life. All in the shadow of a neglectful, careless and insular government.

title: After Theresa May, Boris Johnson? – Cartoon | Opinion
content:
Johnson is a proven twister of the truth, a self-serving self-aggrandising egotist, with a track record of failure, miscalculation, poor judgement, a tendency towards late 19th century colonial values, and the inherited sense of entitlement which every Etonian is automatically handed. A Roger Hargreaves cartoon character made flesh. (Mr Tory).
He’s perfect for the job, then.

The slogans from the far right are similar. The undermining of democratic institutions eg The Daily Mail calling judges 'Enemies of the People' and Trump using a State of emergency to sell weapons and bypassing Congress.
The rubbishing of independent media eg fake news when it's not.
The growing far right is dangerous to democracy and democratic institutions.

title: Book clinic: What can I give a child to help them with losing a parent? | Books
content: Give them your time and your love, and let them know you will always be there for them. Take them out for the day, and if the time is right, visit a bookshop and let them pick something out for themselves. Maybe they’d just want something simple, comforting and escapist, like a comic or a colouring book. There’s no need to overthink it. Surely anything that diverts them from their sadness for a few hours is a blessing.

title: After Theresa May, Boris Johnson? – Cartoon | Opinion
content:
The people have already voted for Brexit. Any new referendum should now be on the question of what type of Brexit they want, and then for parliament to deliver what is decided. May's Soft Brexit, Corbyn's Customs Union, or Johnson's Hard Brexit. The EU has been quite strategic is creating a situation to get a new referendum to overturn Brexit. Quietly watching on the sidelines as May self destructed.
Labour's Watson comment that they have to support a second referendum or risk losing the election. Question is risk losing to whom? Labour still has a high approval rating. And apart from UKIP nothing comes close. LDP - only in London. And UKIP itself may not exist if electoral agency finds election funding anomalies. Change UK - going backwards. Corbyn is the only game in town unless the party officials blow it by intervening.
A second referendum on Brexit is a bad day for democracy because it tells the people who voted for Brexit the first time, that democracy does not work and that Deep State will manipulate the situation until they get the result the elite want. That voting is useless and only a violent uprising will bring about change.

title: Parkville murder: Melbourne reacts with horror as police hunt killer | Australia news | The Guardian
content:
Victoria police said Herron, who had no fixed address, was killed in Royal Park on Friday night. Courtney Herron, a 25-year-old woman of no fixed address, has been identified as the victim of “a horrendous bashing” on Friday night that occurred before she was found dead in Royal Park in Parkville, Melbourne , Victoria police say.
The latest victim of violence directed at a young woman alone on Melbourne’s streets at night, Herron’s death has horrified Melbourne.
“Courtney had experienced issues with drugs and mental health,” Detective Inspector Andrew Stamper, who is leading the investigation into her murder, told reporters on Sunday. “And, as we are all aware, homelessness is often a factor that goes with those two challenges in life. As far as we’re aware, Courtney’s been couch surfing with friends and possibly rough sleeping as well.
“We do have a result from the post-mortem examination that revealed she died as a result of – a horrendous bashing – that’s the only way to describe it.”
Facebook Twitter Pinterest Victoria police mounted branch officers on patrol in Royal Park, Melbourne. Photograph: James Ross/AAP
Stamper said Herron had been initially attacked not far from where her body was found. He said there had been an effort to conceal her body behind a partially burned log.
It was not clear at this stage whether a weapon had been used, he said, adding that it was a particularly horrific attack. The post-mortem had so far indicated Herron had not been sexually assaulted, he said.
Members of the public have started to lay floral tributes at the site where Herron’s body was found, which is a short distance from Princes Park, where Eurydice Dixon’s body was found on 12 June last year. Aiia Maasarwe, 21, was killed on her walk home near La Trobe University on 15 January. Jaymes Todd, 19, has pleaded guilty to the murder and rape of Dixon and will return to court in August, while Codey Herrmann, 20, has been charged with attacking Maasarwe.
In April Natalina Angok’s body was found dumped in Melbourne’s Chinatown, allegedly killed by her one-time partner Christopher Allen, who has been charged.
Facebook Twitter Pinterest Police said there had been an effort to conceal Courtney Herron’s body behind a partially burned log. Photograph: Victoria police
The Victorian premier, Daniel Andrews, said of Herron’s death: “This is a terrible tragedy.
“This is not about the way women behave, this is not about where women are at what hour.
“This is most likely about the behaviour of men.”
Stamper said Victoria police were “very focused on finding the perpetrator of this crime”.
He said it appeared likely Herron had been killed in the park. Her body was was found by dog walkers early on Saturday morning.
Stamper urged anyone that might have been in the area of Royal Park, particularly at Elliott Avenue and its intersection with Flemington Road – one of the major intersections in Melbourne – who saw anything suspicious on Friday night and Saturday morning to contact police.
Police are also speaking to people known to sleep rough in the park. Herron was wearing a black tracksuit, runners and a light brown sleeveless vest, and had long hair, Stamper said.
“We would appeal to anyone in the community, either people who knew Courtney, or didn’t, who may have information to assist us,” he said.
On 14 May, Herron had “contact” with police at St Albans. Police were working to fill in the gaps from that confirmed sighting.
“It’s really important we fill in the gaps of where she’s been, who she was associating with, of recent times,” Stamper said. “These are very key aspects of our investigation.”
Woman found dead in Parkville, Melbourne in 'horrendous crime' Read more
Stamper said Herron had been identified overnight by forensic experts and police had been in touch with her family. He described Herron as being a Melbournian from the inner northern suburbs, whose relationship with her family had been fractured due to her mental health issues.
“Courtney had sporadic contact with her family,” he said. “Again, you know, it’s very much part of the challenge when there’s a child that suffered drug use, mental health issues, family relationships can be fragmented.
“We are dealing with a heart-broken family.”
For locals, the news has also been shocking.
Ned Thompson, who lives locally, left flowers at the Parkville scene to pay his respects.
“It’s just too close to home with Eurydice Dixon,” he told the Herald Sun. “I went to her memorial and I was really moved … This just has to stop.”
Facebook Twitter Pinterest A message on a bouquet of flowers laid at the site where Herron’s body was found in Royal Park. Photograph: James Ross/AAP
Another resident who lives nearby, Peter Chalmers, also spoke to the News Corp paper.
“It is pretty ghastly,” he said. “I walk here every day and often see young girls alone.
“There should be more lights because it’s dark at night.”
A card at the scene reads: “You deserved so much better. May you rest in everlasting peace.”
North Park tennis club head coach Gabriel Moise told the ABC it was “pretty scary” to learn of the discovery of Herron’s body.
“It’s very bad … it’s pretty confronting,” he said.
He said more lighting was needed in the area.
“It is fairly dark in the morning,” he said. “When I open up here [at the tennis courts] it’s pitch black.”
Topics Melbourne Victoria Australian police and policing news

Owens ignored multiple Leinster offsides but picked up every Glasgow one. Leinster slowed the game at every opportunity taking ages over kicks, lying injured at key points then spring back to life like footballers and Owens did nothing about it. Best team lost and that is Rugbys loss.

title: Leinster ruin Stuart Hogg’s farewell to claim Pro14 title against Glasgow

title: Why there is no accounting for a large slice of luck in the Premier League | Greg Wood
content: I’m not sure this credibly establishes the link between XG figures and a different outcome being down to luck. And I’m not sure there ever will be. It’s the reason why so many people love the sport. The human element is so pivotal, yet affects the outcome with so much complexity, that it can never be boiled down to stats. Luck plays a part, but how much players are influenced - or are influenced by it - will remain a mystery.

title: Steve Smith’s century gives Australia World Cup warm-up win over England | Sport
content:
For all those Englishmen who booed Warner and Smith, did you similarly boo Mike Atherton back in 1994? Yeah, I didn't think so. And I don't remember the ECB having the bottle to give Athers a year-long ban. Is my memory failing me? The ICC penalty for Warner and Smith was a one test ban and a match payment fine. CA could have let that be it, but instead stepped in and put Warner and Smith out of all Australian cricket (international, state and even amateur club level) for a year. Now they've served the stiffest penalty ever meted out for fiddling with a cricket ball, they have won their places back.
Now, do you think any Australian players are going to ball tamper in the future? CA has put down a very clear standard; other national cricket organisations, not so much.

title: Home movies: how a coaching inn became a family house – and tiny cinema | Life and style
content: This comment was removed by a moderator because it didn't abide by our community standards . Replies may also be deleted. For more detail see our FAQs .

title: Spice Girls review – nostalgia, branding and bad British values | Music
content:
I don't particularly like them - they are no better or worse than most of the manufactured boy/girl bands of the last 40 or so years.
But FFS sake, stop being so serious about it - when all is said and done it's pop music, not Beethoven.
It's made to be enjoyed by those who love them, and to be ignored by those who don't.
I played enough mediocre rock music myself when I was performing in the 1960s, but I can't remember anyone navel-gazing about my music. I just enjoyed it, as did the people who turned up to listen!

title: Spice Girls review – nostalgia, branding and bad British values | Music
content:
They are what they are.
I’ve always thought they were great manufactured pop, just like many groups. It’s very rare you get a group of girls, women, boys, men, LGBTQ’s , or otherwise, to get together on their own, without the help of a manager or producer, to form a group that can sing, and/or play an instrument.

title: Warndu Mai's saltbush soda bread and Davidson’s plum jam recipes | Food
content: The good news is that at least 6 more people now know a reasonable amount about muntries, and might even find out about a few of the other great native Australian foods that are just there. That can't be bad!

title: Steve Smith’s century gives Australia World Cup warm-up win over England | Sport
content:
It's still amazing, in this day and age, that the Graun cannot provide a link to the real-time scorecard on the OBO. When are you people going to fix this issue? We've been complaining about it forever.
As for the match, a good warm-up for both teams, even with a few regulars missing.
